ySSN NeuroRoutes.About this Series:
NeuroRoutes is a seminar where young research leader share the story of their scientific path and personal growth in academia. By bringing out personal narratives from exceptional young PIs we hope to learn about their research interests, foster motivation and broaden our understanding of various academic pathways. 
These days nearly every scientific on-site event is canceled both in Switzerland and in the rest of the world. In these difficult times, it is increasingly demanding to stay connected and motivated and NeuroRoutes is our answer to this challenge!

The Neurotheory Forum.About this Series: The Neurotheory seminar series is a collaborative effort between current and former labs at the University of Oxford (and now the IST) to study theoretical and computational neuroscience. We now host a online seminar series dubbed the "Neurotheory Forum", which features talks on a wide array of topics in brain science and machine learning.

WWNDev.About this Series: This seminar series covers anything dealing with brain development and evo-devo related questions. From the sources of neuronal diversity to wiring of function-specific circuits, from drosophila to humans, from genes to synapses, in vivo or in vitro, health or disease, it’s all in there for you to watch, question, and get inspired by!

LOOPS de Hoz - Hechavarria.About this Series: Seminars and discussions on subcortico-cortical loops in sensory processing an perception. Every Monday for an hour, an excellent selection of international speakers will talk about their work on subcortico-cortical loops from the perspective of different sensory modalities

Sussex Visions.About this Series: This seminar series covers anything in vision science, with a focus on early circuits (especially vertebrate retina). Despite this primary focus, we aim to broadly include talks from across the field, including both experimental and theory, and across all animals.

Organized by.text: Brain and Mind Doctoral Programme, joint program by the University of Helsinki and Aalto

Brain and Mind Symposium.About this Series:
The Brain and Mind Symposium is a joint effort between the University of Helsinki and Aalto University, funded by the Doctoral Programme in Brain and Mind (Helsinki, Finland). The Student Council of the doctoral program changes every year and consists of doctoral students from various neuroscience backgrounds that volunteer to organize the symposium for students, researchers, and other interested people from both Finland and abroad.
The goal of the symposium is to bring prominent experts from diverse fields of neuroscience to share their knowledge and to stimulate discussion about the advancement of neuroscience and related techniques. Full program at https://www.helsinki.fi/sites/default/files/atoms/files/programme_ver_29_09_2020_0.pdf Free registration at https://www.lyyti.in/BM_Symposium_2020_2595 (deadline: October 8th, 2020)

Duke VisionFest.About this Series: Duke VisionFest is a virtual research symposium conceived to bring together the many Duke groups studying aspects of the visual system. Keynote by Dr. Joseph Carroll, Medical College of Wisconsin, and featuring talks ranging from photoreceptor biology to visual system evolution to clinical diagnosis. Registration is required to attend but open to anyone interested.

Learning Salon.About this Series: In the Learning Salon, we will discuss the similarities and differences between biological and machine learning, including individuals with diverse perspectives and backgrounds, so we can all learn from one another.

Systems Neuroecology.About this Series: Systems Neuroecology is a community of researchers interested in questions that straddle behavioral ecology, ethology, and systems neuroscience.

Organized by.text: Welcome Centre for Integrative Neuroimaging (WIN), Oxford

Brain-Body Interactions.About this Series:
"Ever since its inception, neuroscience has been an integrative discipline, embracing different approaches and fields, and bringing in curious minds from outside the traditional boundaries of the field. After all, Pavlov was mostly interested in digestive glands, but nevertheless ended up being most famous for his contributions to neuroscience. Now more than ever, there is a lot of fascinating science happening at the interface of neuroscience with other biological disciplines. The interaction of the nervous system with metabolism and organ physiology, immunology, reproduction, aging, and cancer, are only a few of the current fertile grounds where neuroscience meets new fields. We decided to term work integrating neuroscience with other biological fields brain-body interactions. Importantly, the integration of neuroscience with other domains of biology not only enables new discoveries, but also allows us to understand how complex interactions within organisms shape emerging properties at the whole-organism level. As such, the insights obtained through such work are key to tackle important challenges ranging from medicine, to nutrition, and food security.

​

This virtual seminar series on brain-body interactions aims to bring together scientists interested in exploring this interface, coming from neuroscience or other fields of biology. By providing an open and integrative forum, we aim at bringing together researchers with a neuroscience background interested in exploring new topics, and colleagues who normally do not work on the nervous system but are interested in learning more about ideas and concepts from neuroscience. As such, we ask our speakers and audience to keep an open mind and an inquiring spirit, and to leave behind the jargon which would normally be suitable for very specialized audiences."

Organized by.text: Neuroscience and Philosophy of Free Will

NeuroPhilosophy of Free Will.About this Series: We are a group of 17 neuroscientists and philosophers have been collaboratively investigating how the brain enables conscious, causal control of decision making and action formation as part of a large, interdisciplinary and international grant.

Neuro Light Lunch.About this Series: This series will highlight 8 rising stars of Canadian neurophotonics with two 30 min talks each week.  This replaces the Canadian Association of Neuroscience Satellite Meeting that was cancelled this year.

CNS 2020.About this Series: The 29th Annual Computational Neuroscience Meeting, CNS 2020, is held online this year and is free of charge. #CNS2020Online

Organized by.text: PhD students from Sainsbury Wellcome Centre and Gatsby Computational Neuroscience Unit

SWC Symposium.About this Series: Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) leverage neural activity to control external effectors – from cursors on two-dimensional screens to artificial limbs with many degrees of freedom. Best known for their use in neuroprosthetics, BMIs provide a powerful tool for basic neurobiological research by enabling experimental control over otherwise inaccessible neural and behavioural parameters. In this student-organised full-day symposium, we will learn about, and discuss, how BMIs can help us understand the possibilities and constraints of neural function.

Organized by.text: The European Reference Network for Rare Neurological Diseases (ERN-RND)

ERN-RND.About this Series: The European Reference Network for Rare Neurological Diseeases (ERN-RND) is a virtual network of expert clinicians located in hospitals all around Europe and working together to improve diagnosis, care and treatment of patients with rare neurological diseases. We organize regular webinars in collaboration with the European Reference Network for Rare Neuromuscular Diseases (EURO-NMD) and the European Academy of Neurology (EAN) with adult/paediatric or neurorehabilitation foci on various aspects from more general  clinical features, examination, disease diagnosis, medical interventions and disease management to more specific ones as use of scales or imaging.

BCCN Berlin.About this Series:
The Bernstein Center for Computational Neuroscience Berlin (BCCN Berlin) is hosting a regular lecture series for master and PhD students, postdocs and senior scientists.
The lectures have a broad spectrum of topics around Computational Neuroscience, including mathematics, physics, computer science, cognitive science, experimental neuroscience, engineering and other.

Organized by.text: María E. Castelló. Desarrolo y Evolución Neural, Instituto de Investigaciones Biológicas Clemente Estable

IIBCE on Brain Science.About this Series: The IIBCE Virtual Seminar on Brain Science seeks to serve as a door of communication of IIBCE and Uruguayan Neuroscientists as well as from the región. Also a channel to the state of the art of International Neuroscience. At the same time, it looks to promote access to knowledge in neuroscience to citizens - as a human right-, for the promotion of brain health throughout life. The conferences will be simultaneously interpreted (English-Spanish) by the Interpreter, MSci Liliana Viera.

NERV.About this Series: The Neural Engineering Research Venture aims to bring computational neuroscience and artificial intelligence to life in Africa and around the world

NYU Swartz.About this Series: The Swartz seminar series covers topics on computational and systems neuroscience

Seaver Autism Center.About this Series: This is the annual seminar series of the Seaver Autism Center for Research and Treaatment at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai (NY). The series features geneticists, neuroscientists, epidemiologists, and stem cell biologists focusing on autism spectrum disorder.

Champalimaud Colloquia.About this Series: Champalimaud Research Colloquia Series is organized by the Champalimaud Centre for the Unknown to promote the discussion about the most interesting and significant questions in neuroscience, physiology and cancer with appointed speakers by the CR Community.

CamNeuro Interdisiciplinary Seminar Seri.About this Series:
Cambridge Neuroscience is bringing together neuroscientists at the University and beyond each term to explore contemporary research in neuroscience and mental health in a new series of seminars. The interdisciplinary programme features current work from across the Schools and Departments, reflecting the pioneering work and diverse interest of members of Cambridge Neuroscience.
Expect up to the minute updates on research, in-depth discussion of key challenges in the field and forward-looking speakers.
In Michaelmas 2020 the series begins with an overview of work in extraordinary circumstances: COVID-19, neuroscience & mental health

Transatlantic Systems Neuro.About this Series: For last two years our project aimed to train young scientists from Central and Easter Europe and promote use of open tools in neuroscience by organizing workshops, seminars and a summer school. Now we move online to host a series on systems neuroscience seminars.

SONA.About this Series: SONA Webinar Series covers a wide range of topics relating to neuroscience. The goal of this series is to make neuroscience more accessible globally. But also, to bring together distinguished neuroscientists with researchers, clinicians and students in Africa through moderated, interactive webinars.

SYNGAP1 by SRF.About this Series: The series is dedicated to increase reaseach on SYNGAP1 mutation disease

NeuroDev Disorders.About this Series: This series covers topics on neurodevelopmental disorders

NeuroLeman Network.About this Series: The NeuroLeman Network is an initiative of neuroscience research labs around the Lake Geneva. The talks hosted cover many different facets of neuroscience from fundamental to cognitive-clinical and computational ones.

Bristol Neuroscience.About this Series: The Bristol Neuroscience Research Network integrates work across the spectrum of neuroscience, mapping mechanisms of brain development and function and identifying new therapeutic targets for neurological and psychiatric disorders. We quantify the dynamics of complex molecular assemblies, signalling processes, neural networks and functions of the nervous system. The Network supports strategic planning and networking across the University of Bristol and the two NHS TRusts through funding bids, events (from smaller workshops of 15 attendees to larger cross-Faculty symposia of over 150 delegates), and recruitment of both staff and students.

McGill Killam Neuro.About this Series: Supported by the generosity of the Killam Trusts, The Neuro’s Killam Seminar series hosts outstanding guest speakers whose research is of interest to the scientific community at The Neuro and McGill University.

Cortex Club.About this Series: The Cortex Club connects researchers at the University of Oxford with world-leading neuroscientists through a unique educational forum dealing with cutting-edge topics and significant challenges in neuroscience. Our events range from small intense debates with up-and-coming scientists to large discussion sessions led by internationally prominent speakers, followed by the opportunity to ask them questions over drinks.

Organized by.text: Picower Institute for Learning and Memory at MIT

IPDGC Africa.About this Series: IPDGC Africa Webinar Series covers a wide range of research on Parkinson’s disease.This series is organized by the The International Parkinson's Disease Genomics Consortium (IPDGC) Africa in partnership with the Society of Neuroscientist of Africa, African Academy of Neurology (AFAN) and TReND in Africa

Ad hoc.About this Series: This is a collection of seminars that are not part of any greater series.  Follow the Join link for more information of the hosts.

SMARTSTART Midsummer Brains.About this Series: SMARTSTART aims to support students during and after their Master’s degree to complement their previous studies with concepts, theories and techniques of Computational Neuroscience. SMARTSTART offers an individual training program, mentoring by experts and a personal travel budget for participation in courses, seasonal schools and conferences. Experts in more than 20 institutions all over Germany support the program.

Neurodegeneration in Flies.About this Series: The fruit fly Drosophila is an incredibly useful model organism for studying neurodegenerative disease due to its short lifespan and wide array of genetic tools. This seminar series brings together researchers from around the globe who study neurodegenerative diseases and age-related neurodegeneration using flies. Our sessions will feature world-leading researchers in the field, as well as early-career researchers, sharing their latest findings in neurodegeneration. All sessions will be held on Thursdays at 16:00 London, UK time, dates and Zoom links at https://www.ucl.ac.uk/biosciences/ucl-iha-virtual-symposium-neurodegeneration-flies

NeuroMath.About this Series:
This seminar series tries to delve into the math behind neuroscience. 


Past talks and live streams can be found https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCcxYsBmui642vZ6KqCYZB-A

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bmlvx9A1C1c&list=PLDrr5kpw_e4uwLubCWf5o34Z2LtolxzR3

Organized by.text: please see here for hosts, speakers & dates

IST Neuroscience.About this Series: IST Austria's Neuroscience Seminar Series covers anything dealing with brain development, biophysics, systems, theoretical and molecular neuroscience. The series is partly given by senior speakers (streamed talks) and students (internal only), taking place every Tuesday during the academic year at 14:00 (CET).

BIU Vision Science.About this Series: BIU Vision Science hosts weekly talks about vision covering a wide range of topics, from mechanisms to high-level perception and action, from retina to brain, from human to machine, in normal and in impaired vision. This is an initiative of the Bar Ilan University School of Optometry and Vision Science. See more details on https://shagido.wixsite.com/biu-vs

NeuroAI UCL.About this Series: A NeuroAI series of talks organised by the UCL NeuroAI community. Talks will continue on a monthly basis with a short break over the summer. ""The last decade has seen phenomenal advances in the field of machine learning (AI) (e.g. deep learning, reinforcement learning). Such is the change that no area of science can afford to ignore it, least of all neuroscience. Crucially, AI shares a common lineage with neuroscience, and provides a means to emulate neural functions and the circuits supporting them, delivering a normative understanding of the brain and cognition (e.g. Banino et al., 2018; Stringer et al. 2019; Dabney et al., 2020). Equally AI tools provide a means to discover, segment, and track distinct neural and behavioural states (e.g. Mathis et al., 2018; Frey et al., 2019) - yielding more efficient experiments and accelerating the pace of discovery. In turn, this understanding feeds back into the design of more effective AI architectures and models (e.g. Sabour et al., 2017; Stringer et al, 2019, Dabney et al., 2020). Essentially, AI problems posed in neuroscience both require and inspire further advances in AI.

neuroEYEscience.About this Series: We are ocular neuroscience team from Department of Physiology, Medical University of Silesia in Katowice, Poland and here you will be able to find seminars related to newest findings in visual neuroscience, especially related to optic nerve structure and function in health and various diseases. We will present also translational implications of visual neuroscience discoveries into clinical settings and breaking through clinical neuroophthalmology aspects.
